content: The "Child Gun Safety and Gun Access Prevention Act of 2001" aims to increase youth gun safety by raising the age of handgun eligibility and prohibiting youth from possessing semiautomatic assault weapons. Section 922(x) of title 18, United States Code is amended to raise the age limit for possessing semiautomatic assault weapons and large capacity ammunition feeding devices to individuals under 21 years of age. The amendment to Section 922(x) of title 18, United States Code raises the age limit for possessing semiautomatic assault weapons and large capacity ammunition feeding devices to individuals under 21 years of age. It includes provisions for temporary possession, possession by individuals under 21 years of age, and possession in defense against intruders into a residence. The amendment to Section 922(x) of title 18, United States Code raises the age limit for possessing semiautomatic assault weapons and large capacity ammunition feeding devices to individuals under 21 years of age. It includes provisions for temporary possession, possession by individuals under 21 years of age, and possession in defense against intruders into a residence. This allows temporary transfer or use of a handgun or ammunition by individuals aged 18 to 21 for specific purposes like employment or ranching/farming activities on the property with permission. The amendment to Section 922(x) of title 18, United States Code raises the age limit for possessing semiautomatic assault weapons and large capacity ammunition feeding devices to individuals under 21 years of age. It allows temporary possession, possession by individuals under 21 years of age, and possession in defense against intruders into a residence. The amendment also permits temporary transfer or use of a handgun or ammunition by individuals aged 18 to 21 for specific purposes like employment or ranching/farming activities on the property with permission. ENHANCED PENALTY for youth possession of handguns and semiautomatic assault weapons, as well as for the transfer of such weapons to youth. Section 924(a)(6) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to impose fines and imprisonment for juveniles violating section 922(x), with harsher penalties for subsequent violations or those committed after a prior delinquency adjudication or conviction for a serious violent felony. Adults who knowingly violate section 922(x) face fines, imprisonment up to five years, or both, with increased penalties if they transfer specified firearms to others. The amendment to section 924(a)(6) of title 18, United States Code imposes fines and imprisonment for transferring a handgun, ammunition, semiautomatic assault weapon, or large capacity ammunition feeding device to a person under 21 years of age with knowledge of their intent to use it in a violent crime. Penalties include fines, imprisonment for up to 10 years, or both. SEC. 4. Gun storage and safety devices required for all firearms. The amendment to Section 922 of title 18, United States Code, requires licensed firearms dealers to provide secure gun storage or safety devices to any person purchasing a firearm. Violation of this requirement may result in license suspension, revocation, or a civil penalty of up to $10,000 as per the amendment to Section 924 of the same title. The Secretary's actions under this subsection may be reviewed only as provided in section 923(f). Repeal of Inconsistent Provisions includes amendments to sections 923(d)(1) and 923(e) of the title. The Department of Commerce, Justice, and State Appropriations Act of 1999 is amended to remove subsection (d), with the effective date of the amendments being 180 days after enactment. SEC. 5. RESPONSIBILITY OF ADULTS FOR DEATH AND INJURY CAUSED BY CHILD ACCESS TO FIREARMS. Section 922 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include provisions regarding the responsibility of adults for child access to firearms. The term 'child' refers to an individual under 18 years old. Any person who keeps a loaded firearm within premises they control, knowing a child could access it and use it to cause harm, will be held accountable. If a child gains access to a firearm and uses it to cause harm, the responsible adult could face up to 3 years in prison, a fine, or both. Exceptions include if the firearm was secured, if the person is a peace officer or in the military, or if the child used the firearm in self-defense or defense of others. The person will not be held liable if a child gains access to a firearm and uses it for harm, unless the firearm was not secured, the person is a peace officer or in the military, or the child used the firearm in self-defense or defense of others. Requirement for children to be accompanied by an adult at gun shows. Requirement for children under 18 to be accompanied by an adult at gun shows, with penalties for violations. The Attorney General can provide grants to local governments for gun safety classes. Applications must be submitted with specific information and assurances. Gun safety classes will be offered at convenient times for parents, including evenings and weekends. The Attorney General will issue necessary regulations for this section. Education: Nationwide firearms safety programs should be provided by each school district for students in grades K-12. Consultation with a certified firearms instructor is recommended for curriculum development. Participation in the program is not mandatory if a parent requests exemption in writing.
